title: Report Traces Source of U.K. Fraud Office Case Delays
text:
The U.K.’s Serious Fraud Office at times has struggled to appropriately staff cases and process digital materials, an independent government inspector said.

The findings were part of a report released Tuesday by Her Majesty’s Crown Prosecution Service Inspectorate, which reviewed six randomly selected SFO cases.

The amount of time it has taken the SFO to resolve certain cases has been the subject of scrutiny in the U.K. The agency’s new director, Lisa Osofsky, has signaled that she will move to close cases that aren’t progressing toward a resolution.

Ms. Osofsky in February announced the SFO was closing long-running probes into GlaxoSmithKline PLC and individuals at subsidiaries of Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC. Several others, including investigations into Kazakh mining group Eurasian Natural Resources Corp Ltd. and GPT Special Project Management Ltd., a subsidiary of aerospace company Airbus SE, are ongoing but have been under investigation for over six years.

The SFO’s caseload has remained relatively consistent in recent years—hovering around 70 to 75 cases, according to the last three fiscal-year reports.

But the majority of the agency’s cases are complex, and can involve terabytes of data, which have to be analyzed and dealt with in accordance with the U.K.’s legal privilege and due process rules, HMCPSI noted on Tuesday.

The review focused on specific case-management practices that HMCPSI found contributed to delays. The SFO has clear case-management processes, but they were at times inconsistently applied, HMCPSI found.

“The report is clear that, while the SFO is effective at what it does, there are further actions we can take to improve case progression,” Ms. Osofsky said in a statement.

After deciding to accept a case, the SFO often took too long to define its parameters or allocate resources to the investigation, HMCPSI said.

A case considered low priority could languish with the agency’s intelligence division, which assesses tips of fraud and corruption and conducts research before a full investigation is launched, according to the inspector.

In some instances, the cases failed to advance for as many as 18 months, HMCPSI said. The inspector said SFO staff reported a lack of clarity into why some cases appeared to be given significantly more priority than others.

Another chokepoint was the SFO’s digital forensic unit, which processes materials from searches, seizures or voluntary surrender, according to Tuesday’s report. The unit has suffered from high staff turnover, according to HMCPSI. Seizure from one large case in particular had put a strain on the unit from which it had yet to recover, the inspector said.

“Resourcing inevitably plays a part in this,” HMCPSI said, referring to the staffing and evidence processing issues. It said the SFO needed to develop a strategic approach to resourcing and case management.

HMCPSI on Tuesday said its report should not be read negatively. “There have been some failures but generally the SFO performs well and has delivered good results in many challenging cases,” the inspector said.

description: The U.K.’s Serious Fraud Office at times has struggled to appropriately staff cases and process digital materials, an independent government inspector said.
